You said:
creating a coupon code to apply for discount in google forms
ChatGPT said:

Google Forms doesn’t have a built-in feature for coupon codes or automated discount calculations — it’s basically just a survey/response collection tool.

If you want to add a coupon code system, you have three main approaches:

1️⃣ Simple Manual Validation (Basic)

  • Add a short answer question: “Enter your coupon code”.

  • In Response validation (⋮ menu > Response validation):

    • Set rule: Text contains YOURCODE.

    • Add custom error message: “Invalid coupon code”.

  • This will only check if the entered text matches exactly — it won’t calculate a discount automatically.

⚠ Limitation:

  • Everyone who sees the form will see the correct code if shared.

  • Can only validate fixed text (no multiple codes or expiration dates).

2️⃣ Multiple Codes Using “Go to section” (Semi-Automated)

  • Create two sections:

    1. Section 1: Ask for the coupon code.

    2. Section 2A: Discount pricing questions (if valid).

    3. Section 2B: Regular pricing questions (if invalid).

  • Use Go to section based on answer logic to route people to the right section.

  • You can set multiple choice answers for common codes.

3️⃣ Advanced Discount Handling with Google Sheets + Apps Script (Automated)

If you want:

  • Multiple coupon codes

  • Expiration dates

  • Automatic discount calculation
    then:

  1. Link your Google Form to a Google Sheet (Responses > Link to Sheets).

  2. Use Google Apps Script in the Sheet to:

    • Check coupon code validity from a stored list.

    • Calculate discount amounts.

    • Optionally send the adjusted payment link or confirmation email.

Example simple Apps Script for validation:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var sheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1");
  var lastRow = sheet.getLastRow();
  var code = sheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue(); // assuming coupon code is column 2
  
  var validCodes = ["WELCOME10", "SAVE20", "HEMANT50"];
  
  if (validCodes.indexOf(code) === -1) {
    sheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).setValue("Invalid code");
  } else {
    sheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).setValue("Valid code applied");
  }
}

💡 Pro tip: If you’re actually collecting payments, Google Forms can’t directly do discounts. You’d need to:

  • Either redirect to a payment page with a pre-discounted price (e.g., Razorpay/Stripe link for that amount)

  • Or send them the correct payment link after verifying the coupon.

If you want, I can prepare a Google Form + Apps Script setup where people enter a coupon code and instantly see the correct payment link after submission. That way it works like a real discount system.

Here’s the step-by-step:

1️⃣ Create the Google Form

  1. Make a new Google Form.

  2. Add:

    • Name (Short answer)

    • Email (Short answer)

    • Coupon Code (Short answer, required)

  3. Done — keep it simple for now.

2️⃣ Link to Google Sheets

  • In the Google Form editor:
    Responses → Link to Sheets → Create new spreadsheet.

  • This will hold all submissions and is where our script will run.

3️⃣ Prepare Your Coupon & Payment Link Table

In your linked Google Sheet:

  1. Create a new sheet (tab) called Coupons.

  2. Add:

    • Column A: Code (e.g., WELCOME10, SAVE20, HEMANT50)

    • Column B: Payment Link (each coupon’s correct discounted payment link)

  3. Example:

CodePayment Link
WELCOME10https://yourpay.com/discount10
SAVE20https://yourpay.com/discount20
HEMANT50https://yourpay.com/discount50

4️⃣ Add the Apps Script

  1. In Google Sheets:
    Extensions → Apps Script

  2. Paste this code:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var formSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1");
  var couponSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  
  var lastRow = formSheet.getLastRow();
  var email = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue(); // Assuming Email is column 2
  var couponCode = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).getValue().trim(); // Assuming Coupon is column 3
  
  var coupons = couponSheet.getRange(2, 1, couponSheet.getLastRow()-1, 2).getValues();
  
  var paymentLink = "";
  for (var i = 0; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0].toUpperCase() === couponCode.toUpperCase()) {
      paymentLink = coupons[i][1];
      break;
    }
  }
  
  if (paymentLink) {
    // Send email with payment link
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Your Discounted Payment Link",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Your coupon code is valid! Use this payment link: <a href='" + paymentLink + "'>" + paymentLink + "</a>"
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Valid - Link sent");
  } else {
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Invalid Coupon Code",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Sorry, the coupon code you entered is not valid."
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Invalid code");
  }
}

5️⃣ Set the Trigger

  • In Apps Script:
    Triggers → Add Trigger → Select function: onFormSubmit → Event: From spreadsheet → On form submit

  • Save and allow permissions (it’ll ask to send emails).

6️⃣ How It Works

  • User fills the form and enters coupon code.

  • Script checks against your Coupons list.

  • If valid → Email with discounted payment link.

  • If invalid → Email telling them it’s wrong.

I can also make this show the correct payment link instantly on the Thank You page instead of via email — but that’s slightly trickier because Google Forms itself can’t directly change the confirmation message dynamically without using an external tool.

5️⃣ Modify the Form Script

In the linked Sheet’s Apps Script:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var formSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1");
  var couponSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  
  var lastRow = formSheet.getLastRow();
  var email = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue(); // Email is col 2
  var couponCode = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).getValue().trim(); // Coupon col 3
  
  var coupons = couponSheet.getRange(2, 1, couponSheet.getLastRow()-1, 2).getValues();
  
  var paymentLink = "";
  for (var i = 0; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0].toUpperCase() === couponCode.toUpperCase()) {
      paymentLink = coupons[i][1];
      break;
    }
  }
  
  // Email them
  if (paymentLink) {
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Your Discounted Payment Link",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Your coupon is valid! Here is your payment link: <a href='" + paymentLink + "'>" + paymentLink + "</a>"
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Valid - Link sent");
  } else {
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Invalid Coupon Code",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Sorry, the coupon code you entered is not valid."
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Invalid code");
  }
}

      arduino

      where {{Coupon_Code}} is replaced with their entered code.

You said:
yes
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — we’ll make you a live-connected payment link page that works with your Coupons sheet.

Here’s the idea:

  • When a user lands on https://yourwebsite.com/payment-redirect?code=XYZ, the page will:

    1. Read XYZ from the URL.

    2. Look it up in your Google Sheet’s Coupons tab.

    3. Show the correct payment link instantly.

  • This means you can change coupon codes or links in your sheet anytime without touching the page.

Step 1 – Publish Your Coupons Sheet to the Web

  1. Open your linked Google Sheet.

  2. Go to File → Share → Publish to the web.

  3. Choose the Coupons tab only, set it to CSV format.

  4. Copy the generated URL — it will look like:

    ruby
    https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/XXX/pub?output=csv

Step 2 – Create Your Redirect Page

Here’s the HTML/JS you’ll use:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<title>Payment Link Redirect</title>
<style>
  body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; text-align: center; padding: 50px; }
  .container { max-width: 500px; margin: auto; }
  .link-box { margin-top: 20px; font-size: 1.2em; }
</style>
</head>
<body>
<div class="container">
  <h1>Checking your coupon...</h1>
  <p id="message">Please wait...</p>
  <div class="link-box" id="paymentLink"></div>
</div>

<script>
  // 1. Get coupon code from URL
  const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
  const userCode = (urlParams.get('code') || "").trim().toUpperCase();

  // 2. URL to your published Coupons sheet as CSV
  const sheetCSV = "YOUR_PUBLISHED_CSV_URL_HERE";

  fetch(sheetCSV)
    .then(response => response.text())
    .then(data => {
      const rows = data.split("\n").map(r => r.split(","));
      let foundLink = "";

      rows.forEach((row, index) => {
        if (index > 0) { // skip header
          const code = (row[0] || "").trim().toUpperCase();
          const link = (row[1] || "").trim();
          if (code === userCode) {
            foundLink = link;
          }
        }
      });

      if (foundLink) {
        document.getElementById("message").innerHTML = "Your coupon is valid!";
        document.getElementById("paymentLink").innerHTML = 
          `<a href="${foundLink}" target="_blank">Click here to pay with your discount</a>`;
      } else {
        document.getElementById("message").innerHTML = "Invalid coupon code.";
      }
    })
    .catch(err => {
      document.getElementById("message").innerHTML = "Error checking coupon.";
      console.error(err);
    });
</script>
</body>
</html>

Step 3 – Set It Up

  1. Replace:

    nginx
    YOUR_PUBLISHED_CSV_URL_HERE

    with the Publish to Web → CSV link from Step 1.

  2. Host this file on:

    • Google Sites (via Embed HTML),

    • GitHub Pages,

    • Netlify,

    • or your own domain.

Step 4 – Connect It to the Form

  • In your Form Redirector settings, send people here:

    arduino
    https://yourwebsite.com/payment-redirect?code={{Coupon_Code}}

✅ Now:

  • User enters coupon in the form.

  • After submission → Redirect to this page → Live lookup from your Google Sheet → Shows correct payment link instantly.

  • Email still sent by your Apps Script for backup.

Yes — there’s a more streamlined way than the Google Forms → redirect page → coupon lookup hack,
especially if your goal is to collect payments with discounts in one smooth step.

Here are better alternatives ranked from easiest to most powerful:

1️⃣ Use Google Forms + Payment Gateway’s Built-in Coupon System

  • Keep the form only for gathering details (name, email, etc.).

  • At the end of the form, always send people to your payment gateway’s checkout page (Razorpay, Stripe, Instamojo, PayPal, etc.).

  • These platforms have coupon codes built in, so you don’t have to manage it with Google Sheets or scripts.

  • You just set up discount codes in the payment platform and give them to customers.

Pros:

  • No coding, no scripts.

  • Handles expired codes, usage limits, and different discounts automatically.

  • Can do percentage or fixed-amount discounts.

Cons:

  • Users see the payment page before applying code (extra click).

  • Less “instant gratification” inside the form itself.

2️⃣ Use a Form Tool That Supports Coupons Natively (Jotform, Tally, Typeform, Paperform)

  • Replace Google Forms with a tool like Jotform or Tally:

    • Built-in coupon/discount fields.

    • Connect directly to Stripe, PayPal, Razorpay.

    • Shows the final price instantly in the form.

  • Example: In Jotform:

    • Add a “Product List” field.

    • Enable Coupons in Payment Settings.

    • Create coupon codes in the form editor.

Pros:

  • Users see the discount applied in real-time before paying.

  • No external pages or manual email steps.

Cons:

  • Free tiers have limited submissions.

  • Slight learning curve for setup.

3️⃣ Build a One-Page Checkout Form with Google Sheets as Backend (Custom Web Form)

  • Use Google Apps Script to make a custom HTML form:

    • Users enter details & coupon code.

    • Script checks your Google Sheet for coupon validity in real-time.

    • Shows final price instantly.

    • Redirects to payment gateway with the correct discounted price.

Pros:

  • Completely under your control.

  • Fully automated — one step, no redirects, no waiting.

Cons:

  • Requires coding (but I can give you the complete script).

  • Hosting needed (can be done for free with Google Apps Script Web App).

My Recommendation for “Best Way”

If you want fast setup → Use your payment gateway’s built-in coupon system.
If you want best user experience → Switch to Jotform/Tally with coupons built in.
If you want full control & free hosting → Let’s build a custom Google Apps Script checkout form that talks to your coupon sheet and payment link instantly.

Alright — let’s build Option 3: a single-page checkout form powered by Google Apps Script that checks your coupon code in real-time and sends the user straight to the correct payment link.

This will be smoother than the Google Forms + redirect trick because:

  • Users see immediate coupon validation before submitting.

  • They skip the “thank you → wait for email” step.

Step 1 – Prepare Your Coupon Sheet

  1. Create a Google Sheet named Coupons.

  2. Add these columns:

CodeDiscount (%)Payment Link
WELCOME1010https://yourpay.com/discount10
SAVE2020https://yourpay.com/discount20
HEMANT5050https://yourpay.com/discount50

Step 2 – Create the Apps Script Web App

  1. In Google Sheets:
    Extensions → Apps Script

  2. Paste this code:

javascript
// Serve the HTML form
function doGet() {
  return HtmlService.createHtmlOutputFromFile('form').setTitle("Event Registration");
}

// API: Check coupon validity
function checkCoupon(code) {
  const sheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  const data = sheet.getRange(2, 1, sheet.getLastRow()-1, 3).getValues();
  const searchCode = code.trim().toUpperCase();

  for (let i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
    if (data[i][0].toUpperCase() === searchCode) {
      return { valid: true, discount: data[i][1], link: data[i][2] };
    }
  }
  return { valid: false };
}

Step 3 – Create the HTML Form (file named form.html)

In Apps Script:
File → New → HTML file → name it form.html
Paste this:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<title>Event Registration</title>
<style>
  body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; max-width: 400px; margin: auto; padding: 20px; }
  input, button { width: 100%; padding: 10px; margin-top: 10px; font-size: 16px; }
  .success { color: green; }
  .error { color: red; }
</style>
</head>
<body>
<h2>Register for the Event</h2>
<input type="text" id="name" placeholder="Your Name" required>
<input type="email" id="email" placeholder="Your Email" required>
<input type="text" id="coupon" placeholder="Coupon Code">
<button onclick="validateCoupon()">Apply Coupon</button>
<p id="couponMsg"></p>
<button id="payBtn" style="display:none;">Proceed to Payment</button>

<script>
let paymentLink = "";

function validateCoupon() {
  const code = document.getElementById("coupon").value;
  google.script.run.withSuccessHandler(function(result) {
    if (result.valid) {
      document.getElementById("couponMsg").innerHTML = 
        `✅ Valid coupon! ${result.discount}% discount applied.`;
      document.getElementById("couponMsg").className = "success";
      paymentLink = result.link;
      document.getElementById("payBtn").style.display = "block";
    } else {
      document.getElementById("couponMsg").innerHTML = "❌ Invalid coupon code.";
      document.getElementById("couponMsg").className = "error";
      document.getElementById("payBtn").style.display = "none";
    }
  }).checkCoupon(code);
}

document.getElementById("payBtn").onclick = function() {
  if (paymentLink) {
    window.open(paymentLink, "_blank");
  }
};
</script>
</body>
</html>

Step 4 – Deploy the Web App

  1. In Apps Script: Deploy → New deployment.

  2. Choose Web App.

  3. Set:

    • Execute as: Me

    • Who has access: Anyone with the link

  4. Click Deploy and copy the link.

ChatGPT said:

Gotcha — when you say "not working", there are a few common reasons why this Apps Script setup fails:

1️⃣ The Coupons sheet name doesn’t match

  • The script has:

javascript
const sheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Coupons");

If your tab name in Google Sheets isn’t exactly Coupons (case-sensitive, no spaces), it will return null and the lookup will fail.
Fix: Rename your tab to Coupons or change the script to your tab’s name.

2️⃣ HTML file not found

  • In the script we use:

javascript
HtmlService.createHtmlOutputFromFile('form')

If your HTML file in Apps Script isn’t named exactly form.html (just form in the create function), you’ll get an error.
Fix: Make sure you created form.html in File → New → HTML file.

3️⃣ You didn’t deploy as a Web App

This method only works if you deploy it:

  • Go to Deploy → New deployment.

  • Select Web app.

  • Set:

    • Execute as: Me

    • Who has access: Anyone

  • Copy the Web App URL and open that, not the script editor preview.

4️⃣ Browser blocking script calls

If you just open the HTML file in a browser without running it from the deployed Apps Script URL,
google.script.run calls won’t work.
Fix: Always open the page using the Web App link from deployment.

5️⃣ Data not starting from row 2

In the script:

javascript
sheet.getRange(2, 1, sheet.getLastRow()-1, 3).getValues();

This assumes:

  • Row 1 is headers (Code | Discount | Payment Link)

  • Data starts from row 2.
    If your data starts on row 1, the first coupon will be skipped.
    Fix: Make sure headers are in row 1.

If you want, I can give you a fixed minimal version of the script that you can paste fresh and will run without changes except your sheet name & data.
That way we’ll know if the problem is deployment or lookup logic.

ChatGPT said:

I see — that “too many redirects” error happens when you try to open your Apps Script Web App link without publishing it correctly or when you try to run it from a URL that’s actually the script editor and not the deployed web app.

Here’s what’s going wrong:

  • You might be opening a link that starts with

    ruby
    https://script.google.com/macros/s/...

    but it’s still in “authorisation” mode instead of the public web app mode.

  • If you aren’t logged into the same Google account that owns the script, Safari will keep trying to log you in → endless redirect.

How to fix the redirect loop

Step 1 – Deploy the web app properly

  1. In Apps Script:
    Deploy → New Deployment

  2. Choose "Web app" from the dropdown.

  3. Under Execute as: choose Me.

  4. Under Who has access: choose Anyone (or Anyone with the link).

  5. Click Deploy and Authorize when prompted.

  6. Copy the new Web App URL — it should look like:

    bash
    https://script.google.com/macros/s/AKfycbyExampleCode/exec

    Important: Use the /exec link, not /dev.

Step 2 – Open in the same account

  • If it’s restricted to “Anyone with the link” and you’re logged into Google, you must open it in the same Google account that owns the script.

  • If you set it to “Anyone” then you can open it from any account or even in private browsing.

Step 3 – Always use /exec

  • /dev = developer mode (requires login and may loop redirects if accounts mismatch).

  • /exec = published version (for public use, no redirect loop).

If you want, I can rewrite your deployment process exactly step-by-step with screenshots so you can avoid this Safari redirect mess completely.

We can absolutely add a coupon code system to it, but since Google Forms itself doesn’t have real-time logic, we’ll need to:

  1. Add a "Coupon Code" question in your form.

  2. Link the form to a Google Sheet.

  3. Add your Coupons tab in that sheet (like your screenshot).

  4. Use Google Apps Script in the sheet to:

    • Check if the coupon is valid when a response comes in.

    • If valid → send them the correct payment link (via email).

    • If invalid → send them a “code invalid” email.

We can also make it so the user sees the payment link instantly after submitting using a redirect add-on, but that’s optional.

Here’s what we’ll do:

Step 1 – Add the Coupon Question

In your Google Form:

  • Add a Short answer question: "Enter your coupon code", make it required.

  • Keep it near the end, before the payment step.

Step 2 – Link to Google Sheets

  • In Form editor → Responses tab → Link to Sheets → New Spreadsheet.

  • This sheet will get all form submissions.

Step 3 – Add Your Coupons Tab

In the linked spreadsheet:

  • Create a new sheet tab called Coupons.

  • Add:

CodeDiscount (%)Payment Link
WELCOME1010https://yourpay.com/discount10
SAVE2020https://yourpay.com/discount20
HEMANT5050https://yourpay.com/discount50

Step 4 – Add the Script

In the linked spreadsheet:

  • Go to Extensions → Apps Script.

  • Paste this:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var formSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1");
  var couponSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  
  var lastRow = formSheet.getLastRow();
  var email = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue(); // assuming Email is column 2
  var couponCode = formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).getValue().trim(); // assuming Coupon is column 3
  
  var coupons = couponSheet.getRange(2, 1, couponSheet.getLastRow()-1, 3).getValues();
  
  var paymentLink = "";
  for (var i = 0; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0].toUpperCase() === couponCode.toUpperCase()) {
      paymentLink = coupons[i][2];
      break;
    }
  }
  
  if (paymentLink) {
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Your Discounted Payment Link",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Your coupon code is valid! Use this link to complete your payment: <a href='" + paymentLink + "'>" + paymentLink + "</a>"
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Valid - Link sent");
  } else {
    MailApp.sendEmail({
      to: email,
      subject: "Invalid Coupon Code",
      htmlBody: "Hi,<br><br>Sorry, the coupon code you entered is not valid."
    });
    formSheet.getRange(lastRow, 4).setValue("Invalid code");
  }
}

Step 5 – Enable the Script Trigger

  • In Apps Script → Clock icon (Triggers) → Add Trigger.

  • Function: onFormSubmit.

  • Event: From spreadsheet → On form submit.

  • Save & allow permissions.

✅ Result:

  • User fills form → enters coupon → submission goes to sheet → script checks code → sends correct payment link or “invalid” email.

  • You don’t need to touch the form again; you just update the Coupons tab for new codes or links.

If you want, I can also make this show the correct payment link instantly after form submission instead of email-only — but that needs a small redirect add-on.

You said:
more detail on 4th option
ChatGPT said:

Got it — here’s the detailed breakdown for Option 4 (Google Pay / PhonePe / UPI QR + short link):

How it Works

Instead of using a payment gateway like Razorpay, you directly share a pre-filled UPI payment link (or QR code) that has:

  • Your UPI ID

  • The fixed amount (₹6499)

  • An optional note like “Artist League Camp - Coupon Applied”

When someone clicks the link, it opens in their UPI app (Google Pay, PhonePe, Paytm, BHIM, etc.) with the amount already filled in.

Step-by-Step Setup

  1. Get Your UPI ID

    • Example: yourname@okaxis, yourname@paytm, or mobile@upi

    • You can find this in your UPI app.

  2. Create the Payment Link

    • Use this format:

      perl
      upi://pay?pa=YOUR-UPI-ID&pn=YOUR-NAME&am=6499&cu=INR&tn=Artist%20League%20Camp

      • pa → Payee address (your UPI ID)

      • pn → Payee name

      • am → Amount (6499)

      • cu → Currency (INR)

      • tn → Transaction note (optional, use %20 for spaces)

      Example:

      perl
      upi://pay?pa=artistcamp@okaxis&pn=Artist%20League&am=6499&cu=INR&tn=Artist%20League%20Camp

  3. Shorten the Link

    • Use bit.ly or TinyURL to make it clean and shareable.
      Example:

      arduino
      https://bit.ly/camp6499

  4. Create a QR Code (Optional)

    • Paste your UPI link into QR Code Generator or your UPI app to create a scannable QR code.

    • You can print this QR or insert it into your form/poster.

Pros

✅ No gateway fees (0%) — full ₹6499 goes to you.
✅ Works instantly for most Indians with UPI apps.
✅ No approval process like Razorpay.
✅ Quick to set up.

Cons

❌ No automatic name/email capture — you’ll need people to send a screenshot or fill in payment reference in your Google Form.
❌ Less professional branding than Razorpay/Instamojo.
❌ Harder to reconcile if many payments come in at once without a proper order ID.

If you want, I can generate one master ₹6499 UPI link + QR code for you, so you can just use it in your coupon flow.
This would let you skip all gateway setup steps entirely.

Do you want me to make that link & QR for you now?

You can create a fixed amount UPI payment link in two main ways:

1. Manual Link Creation (Free, Instant)

You can directly make a link that opens in any UPI app with the amount pre-filled.

Format:

arduino
upi://pay?pa=YOUR-UPI-ID&pn=PAYEE-NAME&am=AMOUNT&cu=INR&tn=NOTE

Parameters:

  • pa → Your UPI ID (example: yourname@okaxis)

  • pn → Your name or business name (use %20 instead of spaces)

  • am → Amount (example: 6499)

  • cu → Currency (INR)

  • tn → Transaction note (optional, but helpful for tracking)

Example:

perl
upi://pay?pa=artistcamp@okaxis&pn=Artist%20League&am=6499&cu=INR&tn=Artist%20League%20Camp

You can then shorten it using bit.ly or TinyURL.

2. Using Your UPI App (Quick, with QR Option)

Google Pay

  • Open Google Pay → Tap New Payment → UPI ID or Number (enter your own UPI ID)

  • Enter ₹6499 and description.

  • Before sending, tap three dots → Get payment link.

PhonePe

  • Go to My QR Code in your profile.

  • There’s usually an “Enter Amount” option for generating a fixed QR.

  • You can share that QR or generate a link from it.

Paytm

  • Go to Accept Payments → Share Payment Link.

  • Set ₹6499, add note, and get link.

✅ Best for events like yours:
Make one fixed ₹6499 link manually (Method 1) → Shorten it → Add it into your Google Form script for all ₹2000-off coupons.
This way, no extra setup or KYC with payment gateways.

2. Link Form to a Google Sheet

  • Open your form → Go to Responses → Click the green Sheets icon to create a linked spreadsheet.

  • This spreadsheet will store responses and we’ll also store the coupon codes in it.

3. Create Coupons Sheet

  • In that linked Google Sheet, create a new sheet called Coupons.

  • Add two columns:

    • Code → e.g. YASH2000

    • PaymentLink → paste the ₹6499 UPI link.

4. Add Apps Script to Validate Coupons

  1. In Google Sheets, click Extensions → Apps Script.

  2. Paste this script (it checks the coupon entered in the form and emails them the correct link):

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var sheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet();
  var couponSheet = sheet.getSheetByName("Coupons");
  var data = couponSheet.getRange(2, 1, couponSheet.getLastRow()-1, 2).getValues();
  
  var responsesSheet = sheet.getSheets()[0];
  var lastRow = responsesSheet.getLastRow();
  var email = responsesSheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue(); // Adjust column index for email
  var coupon = responsesSheet.getRange(lastRow, 3).getValue(); // Adjust column index for coupon
  
  var found = false;
  var paymentLink = "";
  data.forEach(function(row){
    if(row[0].toUpperCase() === coupon.toUpperCase()){
      found = true;
      paymentLink = row[1];
    }
  });
  
  if(found) {
    MailApp.sendEmail(email, "Your Discount Payment Link", 
      "Hello!\n\nYour coupon is valid. Please pay ₹6,499 using this link:\n" + paymentLink);
  } else {
    MailApp.sendEmail(email, "Invalid Coupon Code", 
      "Sorry, the coupon you entered is invalid.");
  }
}

  1. Save the script, give permissions, and set up a trigger:

    • Go to Triggers → Add Trigger → Choose onFormSubmit → Event: On form submit → Save.

5. Add a Coupon Field to Your Form

  • In your form, add a Short Answer field labeled "Coupon Code".

  • Mark it as optional if you want non-discount people to still register.

Step 3 – Add Apps Script

  1. Go to Extensions → Apps Script in the Sheet.

  2. Paste this code:

javascript
function onEdit(e) {
  const sheet = e.source.getActiveSheet();
  const editedRow = e.range.getRow();
  const editedCol = e.range.getColumn();

  // Change to your sheet & column where coupon is entered
  if (sheet.getName() === "Form Responses 1" && editedCol === 3 && editedRow > 1) {
    const coupon = sheet.getRange(editedRow, editedCol).getValue().trim().toUpperCase();
    const couponSheet = e.source.getSheetByName("Coupons");
    const coupons = couponSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

    let found = false;
    for (let i = 1; i < coupons.length; i++) {
      if (coupons[i][0] === coupon) {
        sheet.getRange(editedRow, editedCol + 1).setValue(coupons[i][3]); // Final Amount
        sheet.getRange(editedRow, editedCol + 2).setValue(coupons[i][4]); // Payment Link
        found = true;
        break;
      }
    }

    if (!found) {
      sheet.getRange(editedRow, editedCol + 1).setValue("Invalid Coupon");
      sheet.getRange(editedRow, editedCol + 2).setValue("");
    }
  }
}

Step 4 – Save & Test

  • Save the script → refresh the Sheet.

  • When a new form response arrives, type the coupon code into the coupon column.

  • It should instantly fill the Final Amount and Payment Link.

You said:
if a person is getting a payment link only after submitting form after entering coupon , then how the payment ss would be stored ?
ChatGPT said:

Right — if the payment link is only shown after form submission, then you hit a chicken-and-egg problem:

  • The person submits the form before paying.

  • You can’t get their payment screenshot in that same submission, because they haven’t paid yet.

That means their proof of payment would have to be collected in a second step — either a separate form or by letting them edit their response.

Two practical solutions:

Option 1 – 2-Step Process (Separate Payment Screenshot Form)

  1. Form 1 → Collects Name, Coupon Code, calculates payment link.

  2. After they submit, the confirmation page shows:

    • The payment amount

    • The UPI link/QR

    • A link to Form 2 to upload their payment screenshot.

In Form 2, you ask for:

  • Name (or a unique ID from Form 1)

  • Upload payment screenshot

That keeps things clean but means you have two separate submissions to reconcile.

Option 2 – Let Them Edit Their Response

  1. In your Form settings → Turn on “Allow respondents to edit after submit”.

  2. After they submit and get the payment link, they pay.

  3. They re-open their submission (via the link emailed to them automatically) and upload the payment screenshot in the same form.

This way you have only one row per person in your sheet, and it gets updated with the screenshot later.
Downside — some people forget to come back and upload.

Option 3 – Payment First, Form After (Simpler for tracking)

Instead of giving payment link after form submission,

  • Show the payment QR/UPI ID on the landing page or event info

  • Ask them to pay first

  • Then fill the form with payment details & screenshot.

This removes the need for a second step entirely, but you can’t apply coupon discounts dynamically unless you give them unique links.

If you want to keep coupons + payment screenshots in one form and still have coupon validation, Option 2 is the most realistic.

I can set up your Google Form so:

  • Step 1: They fill the form and enter coupon code.

  • Step 2: They submit, get a confirmation email with:

    • Payment link

    • “Click here to upload payment screenshot” link (edits their response).

You said:
can google form display a message when someon enters the code in the form , like a popup
ChatGPT said:

Unfortunately, Google Forms itself can’t show a live popup or instantly update the amount when someone types a coupon code — it’s not built for real-time field validation.

In Forms:

  • You can only use Response Validation to check if an answer matches certain values (e.g., “Must equal YASSH2000”) and show a static error message if it doesn’t.

  • But you can’t:

    • Dynamically change the price

    • Show a “₹2000 discount applied!” message

    • Hide/Show questions based on the code entered in the same moment

2 Ways to Work Around This

1️⃣ Google Form + Apps Script Email

  • They enter the code → Submit the form

  • Apps Script checks the code → Sends them an email with “Discount applied, pay ₹6499 here: [UPI link]”

  • This is easiest but not “instant” feedback.

2️⃣ Use Google Apps Script Web App Instead of Form

  • You replace your form with a custom form built using Google Apps Script HTML Service

  • In this version, when they type the coupon code, JavaScript can instantly validate and display:

    ✅ Coupon applied! Your final amount is ₹6499
    or
    ❌ Invalid coupon code

  • On submit, it still writes all responses to your Google Sheet and lets them upload screenshots.

This option can look similar to Google Forms but allows live popups and dynamic price updates.

If you want instant popup validation, we’d have to go with Option 2 — basically building you a custom Google Form clone with Apps Script.

no , i mean , someone has filled the form & then they are getting payment link after submitting form, so that will lead to payment page , right after the payment is done , can google take the ss of the payment and add it to the sheet ?
ChatGPT said:

Ah — I get what you mean now.
You’re asking if Google can automatically take a screenshot of the payment success page and store it without the user manually uploading it.

Unfortunately… No, Google Forms (or any Google tool) can’t do that — here’s why:

  • Google Forms doesn’t have permission to “watch” a payment page or capture the screen on a user’s device.

  • UPI payment apps (GPay, PhonePe, Paytm, etc.) also don’t give public APIs to confirm payments and send screenshots automatically.

  • Even if they did, for privacy/security reasons browsers can’t just grab screenshots of another app.

What You Can Do Instead

  1. Automatic Payment Verification (no screenshot needed)

    • Instead of relying on screenshots, use a payment gateway (like Razorpay, Instamojo, Cashfree, PayU).

    • These send instant payment confirmation to your Google Sheet via webhook or Apps Script.

    • No screenshot needed — you’ll know payment status instantly.

  2. Redirect to a “Proof Upload” Step

    • After payment, redirect them to a second short Google Form just for uploading payment proof.

    • You can pre-fill their name, coupon, and amount so they only attach the file.

  3. UPI Deep Links + Payment Capture

    • Some tools like Razorpay Payment Links, Instamojo UPI collect payment and automatically mark it as “Paid” in your system.

    • Still no screenshot, but you get verified payment data.

If your main goal is to avoid chasing people for payment screenshots, option 1 (real-time payment verification) is the cleanest — we can still give discounts via coupon codes and have the payment auto-marked in the sheet.

I can set you up so:

  • Person enters coupon → final amount is calculated → payment link generated via Razorpay (or similar) → payment status auto-updates in your sheet.

Attach this to your main form's linked spreadsheet:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  var sheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet();
  var couponSheet = sheet.getSheetByName("Coupons");
  var responsesSheet = sheet.getSheets()[0];
  
  var lastRow = responsesSheet.getLastRow();
  var couponCode = responsesSheet.getRange(lastRow, 5).getValue().toUpperCase(); // 5th column = Coupon Code
  var found = false;
  var finalPrice = 8499;
  
  var data = couponSheet.getRange(2, 1, couponSheet.getLastRow()-1, 4).getValues();
  
  for (var i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
    if (data[i][0] == couponCode) {
      found = true;
      finalPrice = data[i][3];
      break;
    }
  }
  
  var email = responsesSheet.getRange(lastRow, 2).getValue();
  var name = responsesSheet.getRange(lastRow, 1).getValue();
  
  if (found) {
    sendEmail(name, email, finalPrice);
  } else {
    sendInvalidCouponEmail(name, email);
  }
}

function sendEmail(name, email, price) {
  var paymentLink = "upi://pay?pa=yashmani1996@okhdfcbank&pn=Artist%20League&am=" + price + "&cu=INR&tn=Artist%20League%20Camp%20-%20Coupon%20Applied";
  var screenshotForm = "https://forms.gle/[YOUR_SCREENSHOT_FORM_ID]";
  
  var subject = "Artist League Registration – Payment Details";
  var body = "Hi " + name + ",\n\n" +
             "Your coupon has been applied successfully.\n" +
             "Final Price: ₹" + price + "\n\n" +
             "Step 1 – Pay using UPI: \n" + paymentLink + "\n\n" +
             "Step 2 – Upload payment proof here: \n" + screenshotForm + "\n\n" +
             "Thank you,\nArtist League Team";
  
  MailApp.sendEmail(email, subject, body);
}

function sendInvalidCouponEmail(name, email) {
  var subject = "Artist League Registration – Invalid Coupon";
  var body = "Hi " + name + ",\n\n" +
             "The coupon code you entered is invalid. Please contact the organizer.\n\n" +
             "Thank you,\nArtist League Team";
  
  MailApp.sendEmail(email, subject, body);
}

function onFormSubmit(e) {
  const sheet = e.range.getSheet();
  if (sheet.getName() !== "Form Responses 1") return;

  const row = e.range.getRow();
  const couponCol = 3; // Adjust if Coupon Code column is different
  const finalAmtCol = couponCol + 1;
  const payLinkCol = couponCol + 2;

  const couponCode = sheet.getRange(row, couponCol).getValue().trim().toUpperCase();

  const couponSheet = sheet.getParent().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  const coupons = couponSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  let found = false;
  for (let i = 1; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0] === couponCode) {
      sheet.getRange(row, finalAmtCol).setValue(coupons[i][3]); // Final Amount
      sheet.getRange(row, payLinkCol).setValue(coupons[i][4]); // Payment Link
      found = true;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (!found) {
    sheet.getRange(row, finalAmtCol).setValue("Invalid Coupon");
    sheet.getRange(row, payLinkCol).setValue("");
  }
}

Got it — you basically want the payment link that got auto-filled in the sheet to be automatically sent to the person (instead of you manually copy-pasting).

We can do that with Google Apps Script in two main ways:

Option 1 – Auto Email Payment Link After Form Submit

We add code in the same onFormSubmit function so that as soon as the coupon is verified, the user gets an email with:

  • Their coupon code

  • Final amount

  • Payment link (clickable)

Example:

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  const sheet = e.range.getSheet();
  if (sheet.getName() !== "Form Responses 1") return;

  const row = e.range.getRow();
  const emailCol = 2; // change this to the column where email is stored
  const couponCol = 3; // column where coupon code is stored
  const finalAmtCol = couponCol + 1;
  const payLinkCol = couponCol + 2;

  const email = sheet.getRange(row, emailCol).getValue().trim();
  const couponCode = sheet.getRange(row, couponCol).getValue().trim().toUpperCase();

  const couponSheet = sheet.getParent().getSheetByName("Coupons");
  const coupons = couponSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  let found = false;
  for (let i = 1; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0] === couponCode) {
      const finalAmount = coupons[i][3];
      const paymentLink = coupons[i][4];

      // Fill values in sheet
      sheet.getRange(row, finalAmtCol).setValue(finalAmount);
      sheet.getRange(row, payLinkCol).setValue(paymentLink);

      // Send email
      const subject = "Your Payment Link - Artist League Camp";
      const body = `Hi,\n\nThank you for registering!\n\nCoupon Code: ${couponCode}\nFinal Amount: ₹${finalAmount}\n\nClick here to pay: ${paymentLink}\n\nAfter payment, please upload your screenshot in the link provided.\n\nRegards,\nArtist League Team`;
      MailApp.sendEmail(email, subject, body);

      found = true;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (!found) {
    sheet.getRange(row, finalAmtCol).setValue("Invalid Coupon");
    sheet.getRange(row, payLinkCol).setValue("");
  }
}

How this works:

  1. After form submission, it looks up the coupon.

  2. Auto-fills the Final Amount and Payment Link in the sheet.

  3. Sends the Payment Link to the email the person entered in the form.

but we can:

ChatGPT said:

Yes ✅ — but Google Forms won’t directly append to the same row of your main form.
Instead, the easiest way is:

Method: Merge Both Forms into One Sheet Automatically

We’ll use two forms:

  1. Main Registration Form → Stores name, email, coupon code, etc. in Sheet A.

  2. Screenshot Upload Form → Stores email and screenshot in Sheet B.

Then, using Google Apps Script in your Sheet, we can merge them into one master sheet:

  • When someone uploads a screenshot, the script searches Sheet A for the matching email.

  • It pastes the Google Drive file link into a “Payment Screenshot” column in the same row.

Flow

  1. User fills Registration Form → gets QR code & screenshot upload link in confirmation message.

  2. User uploads screenshot in the Screenshot Upload Form.

  3. Script matches their email in both sheets → adds screenshot Drive link to the right column in Sheet A.

  4. You have a single sheet with all data + screenshot link in one row.

Script Example

Here’s a working sample:

javascript
function mergeScreenshotLinks() {
  const mainSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1"); // main form sheet
  const ssSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Screenshot Responses"); // screenshot form sheet

  const mainData = mainSheet.getDataRange().getValues();
  const ssData = ssSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  const emailIndexMain = 1; // Email column index in main form (0-based)
  const emailIndexSS = 1;   // Email column index in screenshot form (0-based)
  const linkIndexSS = 2;    // File upload link column in screenshot form (0-based)
  const screenshotColumnMain = 6; // Column where you want screenshot link in main form (0-based)

  for (let i = 1; i < ssData.length; i++) {
    const emailSS = ssData[i][emailIndexSS];
    const ssLink = ssData[i][linkIndexSS];

    for (let j = 1; j < mainData.length; j++) {
      if (mainData[j][emailIndexMain] === emailSS && !mainData[j][screenshotColumnMain]) {
        mainSheet.getRange(j + 1, screenshotColumnMain + 1).setValue(ssLink);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
}

We can set this script to auto-run every time a screenshot form is submitted.
That way you don’t have to manually merge anything — your main sheet will always have the screenshot link in the correct row.

Updated Script (Matching by Phone Number)

javascript
function mergeScreenshotLinks() {
  const mainSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1"); // main form sheet
  const ssSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Screenshot Responses"); // screenshot form sheet

  const mainData = mainSheet.getDataRange().getValues();
  const ssData = ssSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  const phoneIndexMain = 2; // Phone column index in main form (0-based)
  const phoneIndexSS = 1;   // Phone column index in screenshot form (0-based)
  const linkIndexSS = 2;    // File upload link column in screenshot form (0-based)
  const screenshotColumnMain = 6; // Column where you want screenshot link in main form (0-based)

  for (let i = 1; i < ssData.length; i++) {
    const phoneSS = String(ssData[i][phoneIndexSS]).trim();
    const ssLink = ssData[i][linkIndexSS];

    for (let j = 1; j < mainData.length; j++) {
      const phoneMain = String(mainData[j][phoneIndexMain]).trim();
      if (phoneMain === phoneSS && !mainData[j][screenshotColumnMain]) {
        mainSheet.getRange(j + 1, screenshotColumnMain + 1).setValue(ssLink);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
}

How it Works

  1. Main Form collects phone number → stores in "Form Responses 1".

  2. Screenshot Upload Form also collects the same phone number + payment screenshot.

  3. Script looks for a matching phone number in both sheets.

  4. If it finds a match, it inserts the Drive screenshot link into the right column of the main sheet.

  • Phone (or Contact No.)

  • Coupon Code

  • Final Amount (empty – script fills)

  • Payment Link (empty – script fills)

  • Payment Proof Link (empty – merge script fills later)

If Final Amount, Payment Link, or Payment Proof Link don’t exist yet, insert them as new columns with these headers.

3) Auto-apply coupon on submit (and email link if you want)

Open Extensions → Apps Script on the spreadsheet that contains both tabs.
Create a new script and paste this (it’s header-based, so you don’t have to worry about column numbers):

javascript
/*****  A) COUPON VALIDATION ON MAIN FORM SUBMIT  *****/
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  const activeSheet = e.range.getSheet();
  if (activeSheet.getName() !== 'Form Responses 1') return;

  const ss = activeSheet.getParent();
  const headers = getHeaders_(activeSheet);
  const row = e.range.getRow();

  // REQUIRED headers in main sheet (any order is fine)
  const NAME = col_(headers, ['Name']);
  const EMAIL = col_(headers, ['Email','E-mail']);
  const PHONE = col_(headers, ['Phone','Contact No','Contact Number','Mobile']);
  const COUPON = col_(headers, ['Coupon Code','Coupon']);

  const FINAL = ensureCol_(activeSheet, headers, 'Final Amount');
  const PAYLINK = ensureCol_(activeSheet, headers, 'Payment Link');

  const code = String(activeSheet.getRange(row, COUPON).getValue()).trim().toUpperCase();
  if (!code) return;

  const couponSheet = ss.getSheetByName('Coupons');
  if (!couponSheet) {
    activeSheet.getRange(row, FINAL).setValue('Coupons sheet missing');
    return;
  }

  // Coupons: Code | Original | Discount | Final | Payment Link
  const cVals = couponSheet.getRange(2,1, Math.max(0,couponSheet.getLastRow()-1), 5).getValues();

  let found = false, finalAmt = '', pLink = '';
  for (let i=0;i<cVals.length;i++){
    const c = String(cVals[i][0]||'').trim().toUpperCase();
    if (c === code){
      finalAmt = cVals[i][3];
      pLink = cVals[i][4];
      found = true;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (found){
    activeSheet.getRange(row, FINAL).setValue(finalAmt);
    activeSheet.getRange(row, PAYLINK).setValue(pLink);

    // OPTIONAL: auto email payment link to the respondent
    const SEND_EMAIL = true; // set to false if you don't want emails
    if (SEND_EMAIL && EMAIL){
      const name = NAME ? activeSheet.getRange(row, NAME).getValue() : '';
      const email = activeSheet.getRange(row, EMAIL).getValue();
      const screenshotFormLink = 'https://forms.gle/PUT-YOUR-SCREENSHOT-FORM-ID-HERE';

      const subject = 'Artist League – Your payment link';
      const body =
        'Hi ' + (name||'') + ',\n\n' +
        'Coupon: ' + code + '\n' +
        'Final Amount: ₹' + finalAmt + '\n\n' +
        'Pay here: ' + pLink + '\n' +
        'Then upload your payment screenshot here: ' + screenshotFormLink + '\n\n' +
        'Thanks,\nArtist League';
      if (email) MailApp.sendEmail(email, subject, body);
    }
  } else {
    activeSheet.getRange(row, FINAL).setValue('Invalid Coupon');
    activeSheet.getRange(row, PAYLINK).setValue('');
  }
}

/*****  B) MERGE PAYMENT SCREENSHOT BY PHONE (runs when Screenshot form submits)  *****/
function onScreenshotSubmit(e){
  const sheet = e.range.getSheet();
  if (sheet.getName() !== 'Screenshot Responses') return; // name this tab exactly

  const ss = sheet.getParent();
  const main = ss.getSheetByName('Form Responses 1');
  if (!main) return;

  const ssHeaders = getHeaders_(sheet);
  const mainHeaders = getHeaders_(main);

  const PHONE_SS = col_(ssHeaders, ['Phone','Contact No','Contact Number','Mobile']);
  const PROOF_SS = col_(ssHeaders, ['Payment Screenshot','Screenshot','Proof']); // file upload question column

  const PHONE_MAIN = col_(mainHeaders, ['Phone','Contact No','Contact Number','Mobile']);
  const PROOF_MAIN = ensureCol_(main, mainHeaders, 'Payment Proof Link');

  const r = e.range.getRow();
  const phone = String(sheet.getRange(r, PHONE_SS).getValue()).trim();

  // Get the file URL from the rich text (for file upload cells)
  const proofCell = sheet.getRange(r, PROOF_SS);
  let proofUrl = '';
  const rtv = proofCell.getRichTextValue();
  if (rtv && rtv.getLinkUrl()) {
    proofUrl = rtv.getLinkUrl();                // single link
  } else {
    proofUrl = String(proofCell.getValue());    // fallback (may be filename or comma-separated)
  }

  if (!phone || !proofUrl) return;

  const lastRow = main.getLastRow();
  const phoneVals = main.getRange(2, PHONE_MAIN, Math.max(0, lastRow-1), 1).getValues();

  for (let i=0;i<phoneVals.length;i++){
    const p = String(phoneVals[i][0]||'').trim();
    if (p && p === phone){
      main.getRange(i+2, PROOF_MAIN).setValue(proofUrl);
      break;
    }
  }
}

/*****  Helpers *****/
function getHeaders_(sheet){
  return sheet.getRange(1,1,1, sheet.getLastColumn()).getValues()[0];
}
function col_(headers, names){
  for (let n of names){
    const idx = headers.findIndex(h => String(h).trim().toLowerCase() === String(n).trim().toLowerCase());
    if (idx !== -1) return idx+1;
  }
  return 0; // not found
}
function ensureCol_(sheet, headers, headerName){
  let idx = headers.findIndex(h => String(h).trim().toLowerCase() === headerName.toLowerCase());
  if (idx !== -1) return idx+1;
  // append a new column with this header
  const newCol = sheet.getLastColumn()+1;
  sheet.getRange(1, newCol).setValue(headerName);
  return newCol;
}

Turn on the triggers (one-time):

    1. Function: onFormSubmit → Event type: From spreadsheet → On form submit

    2. Function: onScreenshotSubmit → Event type: From spreadsheet → On form submit
      (this second trigger will fire when the “Screenshot Responses” tab gets a new row)

Authorize when prompted.

3️⃣ Apps Script (paste in Extensions → Apps Script)

javascript
function onFormSubmit(e) {
  const sheet = e.source.getActiveSheet();
  if (sheet.getName() !== "Form Responses 1") return;

  const couponsSheet = e.source.getSheetByName("Coupons");
  const coupons = couponsSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  const row = e.range.getRow();
  const couponCode = sheet.getRange(row, 4).getValue().toString().trim().toUpperCase();

  // Match coupon
  for (let i = 1; i < coupons.length; i++) {
    if (coupons[i][0] === couponCode) {
      sheet.getRange(row, 5).setValue(coupons[i][3]); // Final Amount
      sheet.getRange(row, 6).setValue(coupons[i][4]); // Payment Link
      break;
    }
  }
}

// Function to match screenshot uploads by Phone Number
function matchScreenshotUploads() {
  const mainSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Form Responses 1");
  const ssSheet = SpreadsheetApp.getActiveSpreadsheet().getSheetByName("Screenshot Uploads");

  const mainData = mainSheet.getDataRange().getValues();
  const ssData = ssSheet.getDataRange().getValues();

  // Phone number is column 3 in main form, screenshot link is column 2 in screenshot form
  for (let i = 1; i < mainData.length; i++) {
    let phone = mainData[i][2];
    if (!phone) continue;

    for (let j = 1; j < ssData.length; j++) {
      if (ssData[j][1] == phone) {
        mainSheet.getRange(i + 1, 7).setValue(ssData[j][2]); // Set Screenshot Link
      }
    }
  }
}

4️⃣ How the flow works

  1. User fills Main Form → enters Phone Number + Coupon Code.

  2. Apps Script auto-fills Final Amount + Payment Link in your sheet.

  3. On the Thank You Page, you show:

    • QR Code for UPI payment (same as payment link)

    • Link to Screenshot Upload Form.

  4. In Screenshot Upload Form:

    • They enter Phone Number (must match main form).

    • They upload the payment screenshot.

  5. The matchScreenshotUploads() function matches phone numbers and pastes the screenshot’s Drive link in the same row in your main sheet.

i meant , can we use bit.ly

Ah — got it now 👍.
Yes, you can absolutely use Bitly (or any URL shortener like tinyurl.com) to make the UPI link clickable in the Google Form’s thank-you page.

Here’s why it works:

  • Google Forms automatically detects https:// links and makes them clickable.

  • UPI links (upi://) aren’t clickable because Google Forms doesn’t recognize that protocol.

  • So, we just wrap the UPI link inside a Bitly link — the Bitly link will be clickable, and when clicked on mobile, it will still open the UPI app.

Example:

  1. Take your UPI link:

    perl
    upi://pay?pa=yashmani1996@okhdfcbank&pn=Artist%20League&am=6499&cu=INR

  2. Go to bitly.com → Paste the UPI link → Get a shortened link like:

    arduino
    https://bit.ly/ALCpayment

  3. Use this shortened link in your Coupons sheet instead of the raw UPI link.

  4. When the script puts it in the thank-you page or email, it will be clickable.

Gotcha — so if you don’t have a payment gateway, you’re probably just using a UPI link like:

perl
upi://pay?pa=yourupi@bank&pn=Your%20Name&am=XXX&cu=INR&tn=Description

  • UPI links don’t open directly in browsers like a normal website link.

  • That’s why bit.ly and other shorteners often fail — they’re not designed for deep links like upi:// schemes.

  • The safest way is to either put the QR code directly on your landing page, or use a Google Pay / PhonePe / Paytm payment page which gives you a normal HTTPS link.

Two workable solutions:

1. Pure QR method

  • Show the UPI QR on the landing page.

  • Add a text note: "Scan to pay via GPay / PhonePe / Paytm".

  • Below it, give the screenshot upload form link.

2. UPI link wrapped in HTML

  • You can create a small HTML landing page with a “Pay Now” button.

  • That button uses the UPI link directly (upi://pay?...).

  • This way, it works when opened on a phone with UPI apps installed.

If you want, I can make you a ready-to-use HTML landing page where:

  • Your QR code is visible.

  • A "Pay via UPI" button opens the payment request in UPI apps.

  • Below that, there’s a button to upload the screenshot.

Do you want me to prepare that HTML for you? That would solve the bit.ly problem entirely.
